Description: The 'Cart Add' metric shows the number of times a visitor added something to their cart. This metric is helpful when you want to understand the part of the conversion funnel where customers are interested enough in a product to add it to their cart.
Notes: By combining 'Product' and 'Model Code (v41)' dimensions, you can track the specific products that users added to their cart.
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with cart add.

Description: The ‘Cart removals’ metric shows the number of times a visitor removed something from their cart. This metric is helpful when you want to understand the part of the conversion funnel where customers are no longer interested in a product.
Notes: By combining 'Product' and 'Model Code (v41)' dimensions, you can track the specific products that users removed from their cart.
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with cart remove.

Description: The ‘Cart views’ metric shows the number of times a visitor viewed their shopping cart. This metric is helpful when you want to understand the part of the conversion funnel where customers view the contents in their cart.
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with cart view.

Description: The 'Checkout' event fires at the last step of the checkout process, right before the user is taken to an external payment gateway or popup window to complete the transaction.
Notes: By combining 'eCommerce - Payment Method (v37)' dimension, you can identify which payment option customers attempted to use during their purchase.
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with checkout.

Description: The ‘Orders’ metric shows the total number of purchase events made on your site. This metric is vital for eCommerce sites in measuring conversion.
Notes:
The Order metric includes both orders collected directly by Adobe Analytics and those adjusted through Hybris API integration.

However, please note that in European countries (excluding France) and Turkey, data from users who do not consent to cookie collection cannot be captured in Adobe Analytics. As a result, the Order figures in Adobe Analytics may not fully align with those shown in the BI Dashboard.
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with purchase.

Description: The ‘Orders per visit’ metric shows the ratio of orders that visitors made over the total number of visits to your site. You can use this metric to understand conversion rate for your site.
DataFeed Notes: COUNT(*) FILTER (WHERE regexp_matches(',' || post_event_list || ',', '.*,1,.*')) * 1.0 / COUNT(distinct concat(post_visid_high,post_visid_low))

Description: The ‘Revenue’ metric shows the monetary amount of products purchased within all orders.
Notes:
The revenue is captured based on the final transaction amount paid by the customer, which includes VAT. As a result, it may differ from the BI Dashboard Revenue, where VAT is typically excluded.

Please note that in European countries (excluding France) and Turkey, data from users who do not consent to cookie collection cannot be captured in Adobe Analytics.
DataFeed Notes: Parse the post_product_list column to extract all price data, then sum the number of price in the product string to calculate revenue.

Description: The ‘Units’ metric shows the total number of products purchased within all orders.
DataFeed Notes: Parse the post_product_list column to extract all price data, then sum the number of quantity in the product string to calculate units.

Description: The ‘Product views’ metric shows the number of times any product was viewed. This metric is useful when you want to see your top-viewed products, or see how total product views trend over time.
Notes: By combining 'Product' and 'Model Code (v41)' dimensions, you can track which specific products users have viewed
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with product view.

Description: The ‘Bounces’ metric shows the number of visits that contained exactly one hit. You can use this metric to understand the ratio of bounce to non-bounce traffic you get, to see the top entry pages that cause visitors to bounce, or to see how the total number of bounces trend over time.
DataFeed Notes: count concat(post_visid_high, post_visid_low, visit_num, visit_start_time_gmt) group by concat(post_visid_high, post_visid_low, visit_num, visit_start_time_gmt) having count(*) =1

Description: The ‘Bounce rate’ metric shows the ratio of visits that contained exactly one hit compared to the number of visits entering on that page. You can use this metric to understand which dimension items have the highest bounce rate, or to see an aggregated total bounce rate of your site over time. High bounce rates can shed light on issues with your site or app, such as: poor design, slow loading times, irrelevant content, or a mismatch between visitor intent and page content.

The ‘Occurrences’ metric shows the number of hits where a given dimension was set or persisted. When you drag a dimension in Workspace to a blank canvas, Adobe automatically applies this metric to the project.
DataFeed Notes: Count the total number of rows.

Description:
- Triggered when the application crashed before closing. (=when an App is "closed unexpectedly")
- The Crashes event is sent when the application is started after the crash
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with mobilecrashes.

Description:
Triggered at the first run after installation or re-installation
- ‘Fist Launches’ is not counted when the app version had been upgraded
- ‘Launches’ metric includes the ‘First Launches’
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with mobileinstalls.

Description:
- “Launches” is the base event triggered during every application run, including instances of crashes, upgrades, and app installs
- It is also triggered when the app is resumed from the background after the lifecycle session timeout has been exceeded
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with mobilelaunches.

Description: Triggered at the first run after the upgrade or when the App version number changes
DataFeed Notes: Use event.tsv to match numeric values with mobileupgrades.

Description: The ‘Average page depth’ metric shows how far a dimension item extends into a given visit, on average. For example, your Home page (which is a dimension item for the Page dimension) typically shows a smaller average page depth than your Purchase Confirmation page, which likely extends further into a visit. You can use this information to optimize certain pages toward fresh visitors if the page has a low depth, on average.
DataFeed Notes:
floor(avg(page_order)) 
ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY visitID ORDER BY cust_hit_time_gmt) AS page_order
where  post_pagename is not null

Description: The ‘Average page views per visit’ dimension shows how many page views occurred on average against your desired dimension. For time-based dimensions, you can see how the average number of page views within a visit trends over time. This metric is helpful when you want to understand how frequently dimension items appear in a visit.
DataFeed Notes: COUNT(*) FILTER (WHERE post_page_event =0 and post_pagename is not null) * 1.0 / COUNT(distinct visitID)

Description: The ‘Entries’ metric shows the number of times a given dimension item is captured as the first value in a visit. This metric is helpful when you want to understand more about the first impressions visitors have on your site. Seeing the first values of a dimension can help you understand and optimize the experience a new visitor gets.
DataFeed Notes: Count(distinct(concat(post_visid_high,post_visid_low))) ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY visitID ORDER BY date_time ASC) AS rn where rn = 1

Description: The ‘Exits’ metric shows the number of times a given dimension item is captured as the last value in a visit. This metric is helpful when you want to understand more about the last thing visitors see before leaving your site. Seeing the last values of a dimension can help you understand and optimize the experience a visitor gets before they leave.
DataFeed Notes: Count(distinct(concat(post_visid_high,post_visid_low))) ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY visitID ORDER BY date_time DESC) AS rn where rn = 1

Description:
The ‘Page events’ metric shows the number of times any link tracking call was made. This metric is helpful when you want to understand which pages have the most engaging content. Measurement for this metric is most valuable when a visitor can perform an action on the page without navigating to a new page.

For example, in a typical journey of an eCommerce site, a visitor can have several interactions on a single page. A typical Analytics implementation has these interactions configured as a link tracking (tl()) call, while a page view (t()) call is reserved for the initial page load. This implementation method provides enriched event tracking that provides insight around what interactions happen before a visitor continues their journey.
DataFeed Notes: count(*) where post_page_event !=0

Description: The Page views metric shows the number of times that a given dimension item was set or persisted on a page. It is one of the most common and basic metrics in reports.

The ‘Pages not found’ metric shows the number of hits where a dimension was set or persisted at the time a visitor encountered an error. This metric is valuable when you want to see which pages or URLs contained error messages (such as a 404). You can then pass this information on to your web development team, who can determine the cause of the error and fix it.
DataFeed Notes: count(*) where page_type is not null

Description: The ‘Reloads’ metric shows the number of times a dimension item was present during a reload. A visitor refreshing their browser is the most common way to trigger a reload.
DataFeed Notes:
CASE 
    WHEN post_pagename = LAG(post_pagename) OVER (PARTITION BY visitID ORDER BY CAST(cust_hit_time_gmt AS BIGINT))
    THEN 1
    ELSE 0
  END AS reload

Description: The Single page visits metric shows the number of visits where the Page dimension item contained only a single unique value for the entire visit. This metric is helpful in the context of dimensions where you want to see short visits, but not have as stringent of a rule as Bounces does.
DataFeed Notes: Count(distinct(concat(post_visid_high,post_visid_low))) where post_page_event = 0 group by Count(distinct(concat(post_visid_high,post_visid_low)))  having count(*)=1

Description:
The ‘Average time on site’ metric shows the amount of time that passed between hits for a given dimension item. This metric is helpful when you want to see average time spent for specific dimension items. You can also trend this metric over time to see how overall time spent changes. This metric displays in HH:MM:SS format.

This metric is related to the Time spent per visit dimension.
DataFeed Notes:
1. Concatenate post_visid_high, post_visid_low, visit_num, and visit_start_time_gmt.
2. Sort by this concatenated value, then apply a secondary sort by visit_page_num.
3. If a hit is not the last one in a visit, subtract the post_cust_hit_time value from the subsequent hit’s post_cust_hit_time value.
4. This number is the amount of time spent (in seconds) for the hit. Filters can be applied to focus on dimension items or events.

AVG(CAST(MAX(cust_hit_time_gmt) AS BIGINT) - CAST(MIN(visit_start_time_gmt) AS BIGINT))

Description:
The ‘Time spent per visit (seconds)’ metric shows the average amount of time that visitors interact with a given dimension item during each visit.

This metric is not available in Data Warehouse due to its different processing architecture.
DataFeed Notes: CAST(MAX(cust_hit_time_gmt) AS BIGINT) - CAST(MIN(visit_start_time_gmt) AS BIGINT) group by visitorID

Description:
The Time spent per visitor (seconds) metric shows the average amount of time that visitors interact with a given dimension item during a visitor’s entire lifetime.

This metric is not available in Data Warehouse due to its different processing architecture.
DataFeed Notes: CAST(MAX(cust_hit_time_gmt) AS BIGINT) - CAST(MIN(visit_start_time_gmt) AS BIGINT) group by visitorID

Description: The ‘Unique visitors’ metric shows the number of visitor IDs for the dimension item. It is one of the most common metrics used when determining traffic, as it gives a high-level overview of the popularity of a dimension item. For example, a visitor can come to your site every day for a month, but they still count as a single unique visitor.
DataFeed Notes: count(distinct(concat(post_visid_high,post_visid_low)))

Description: The ‘Visits’ metric shows the number of sessions across all visitors on your site.
Notes: Visit ends when the user is inactive for 30 minutes.
DataFeed Notes:
Concatenate post_visid_high, post_visid_low, visit_num, and visit_start_time_gmt.
Count the unique number of values.
